topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538d40546368722df0670400#post_538d40546368722df0670400
Here's a frog to never squish, the Poison Arrow Frog, a frog that secretes poison from it's skin that is so potent, just touching it can kill you. In fact just the residue is enough to kill a grown man. If you were to step on a rock that the frog was sitting on with your bare foot, the poison it left behind is all it would take. The amount that can fit on the head of a pin can kill 10 men.

It's only found in the Amazon, so unless you are going to the rainforest you have nothing to fear, and trust me that frog is the _least_ of your worries out there...

Here's some cute little critters you get to meet in the rain forest:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eunectes_murinus
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scolopendra_gigantea
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goliath_bird_eating_spider

And don't forget the little critters you can't see:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leishmaniasis
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chagas_disease

topics.body:
Well, "apparently an ancient retrovirus was resurrected in 2007.":http://newswire.rockefeller.edu/2007/02/20/an-ancient-retrovirus-is-resurrected/ Not only is it fascinating that the DNA from this retrovirus was actually found in the human genome, it also made me learn about creating a functional consensus sequence from a non-functional gene.

This has big implications for Jack Horner's dino-chicken project. Two enamel-creating genes are still in the chicken genome, but they are non-functional due to mutations after millions of years of evolution. However, a consensus sequence of those two genes could be deduced, synthesized, and made functional. There is still the issue of the other two enamel genes though, which are missing from the chicken genome entirely.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097
